awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Maintenance Planning for Complex Systems in  Dynamic Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Equipment failures in capital-intensive industries, such as oil and gas exploration, aerospace, and power generation, may threaten human lives and have significant environmental and economic impact.  Many of these equipment failures can be traced to poor equipment maintenance.  One criticism of existing maintenance planning is that the existing predictive failure models do not accurately reflect degradation resulting from multiple causes in dynamic environments.  This project addresses the need for better planning models and analysis to enhance equipment reliability in capital-intensive industries.  The PIs have established collaborations with industrial partners to ensure the relevance of their research.  Educational opportunities for students, including outreach to underrepresented minorities, is also supported by the award.  

This award will support research on a general and systematic methodology for effective reliability modeling and maintenance planning for critical complex systems in capital-intensive industries.  To successfully accomplish the goal, four specific objectives will be achieved: (1) developing a broad class of general stochastic models that can integrally handle the complexities of degradation processes under dynamic environments; (2) constructing general stochastic-modulated multi-dimensional stochastic processes to model the multiple dependent degradation processes under dynamic environments; (3) creating a general mixture degradation framework to capture heterogeneities at both population and unit-levels; and (4) developing a unified maintenance decision-making framework that jointly integrates long-term maintenance planning and short-term dynamic decisions. Successful development of these models will lead to fundamentally new perspectives on the application of reliability and maintenance optimization for complex engineered systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The research objective of this award is to develop a general and systematic decision framework for reliability modeling and maintenance optimization strategies that provide fundamental insights for the successful development and operations of complex systems in capital-intensive industries. One of the critical challenges facing these industries is how to improve the reliability performance of critical equipment at lower costs, and avoid disastrous failures caused by unreliable equipment. Yet existing reliability models/methodologies fall far short when addressing emerging concerns regarding reliability and maintenance of these complex systems. This research utilizes an innovative and effective study of reliability and maintenance to generate models and analysis tools critical to ensure continuous and safe system operations.

Intellectual Merit

The successful implementation of the six tasks in this research has: (1) provided a solid multidisciplinary scientific foundation to combine methodologies in reliability, maintenance, statistics and operations research that can be extended and applied to different disciplines and applications, (2) advanced the state-of-the-art on reliability and maintenance for capital-intensive systems by contributing significant and applicable concepts, models and analysis tools, and (3) offered fundamental insights that can be transformed to many new manufacturing problems, such as superconductor manufacturing that also has unique challenges. The research has produced accurate reliability models and systematic maintenance decision-making support that can directly benefit decision-makers in capital-intensive industries. The research outcomes and findings from each task are summarized as follows:

(1) The first research effort was to develop a broad class of general stochastic models for describing continuous degradation with random jumps, which integrally handle the complexities caused by both intrinsic and extrinsic stochastic properties under dynamic environments. Using the general stochastic models, the systematic procedures are also developed to conduct reliability analysis. (2) For the multiple dependent degradation processes under dynamic environments, we constructed general stochastic-modulated multi-dimensional stochastic processes. The dependence among all dimensions is described by L?vy copulas and the associated multiple-dimensional L?vy measure. The Laplace transforms of both reliability function and lifetime moments were also derived. (3) For multiple dependent degradation processes, we developed a mixture degradation framework to capture heterogeneities at both population and unit-levels. We modeled the dependence between degradation processes using general copula functions and modeled the unit-level heterogeneity as random effects. (4) For maintenance of complex multi-component systems, we developed a unified maintenance decision-framework by jointly integrating long-term maintenance planning and short-term dynamic decisions. The long-term system-level inspection planning is based on historical failure/degradation data, and the short-term decision is based on dynamic maintenance grouping using information at the component level. (5) For estimating and prognosticating the reliability function and lifetime moments, we developed a systematic statistical inference method to construct the point estimates and confidence intervals using linear programing estimators and empirical characteristic functions. (6) Finally, we conducted the proof-of-concept experiments with our industry partners, by providing demonstration, validation, and performance assessment of the developed models and algorithms. The collaboration promotes a quicker transfer of technology into industries and the feedback from industries improves both research and curriculum development.

Broader Impacts

The models and analytical tools developed in this research have contributed to generate broader economic impact through optimized operational decisions in industrial implementation, such as enhanced reliability, improved productivity, and lower costs. A solid multidisciplinary scientific foundation has been built to combine methodologies in reliability, maintenance, statistics and operations research.

Three doctoral students have been supported to work on this research, including one female student. During the project period, two doctoral students successfully defended/proposed their dissertations as the direct results from this project. They are exposed to reliability, maintenance, and operation problems in capital-intensive industries such as oil and gas, wind turbines and high-temperature superconductors. They are trained to conduct extensive literature review, identify research problems, develop models independently, and solve problems using numerical methods or simulation studies. As a result, each of them has completed at least two high-quality journal manuscripts. Students are also encouraged to present papers and attend doctoral colloquiums at conferences. Dr. Feng and her students have disseminated their research findings by making presentations at multiple national and international conferences in five years. The experiences helped the students to improve their presentation skills, and provided them excellent networking opportunities for their future careers.


Last Modified: 12/26/2022
Modified by: Qianmei Feng
